A majority of flu-positive patients had either pulmonary or heart disease backgrounds, in line with their ages. Most often older adults or those with chronic pulmonary, cardiac, and metabolic or other disease have a more complicated influenza illness with subsequent secondary bacterial infections.

17, 18 However, the frequency of positive results decreased from nasopharyngeal (65%) to throat swab (30%) to sputum (5%) samples. This finding suggests that the molecular influenza tests show different sensitivity depending on the specimen types, being the difference in favor of nasopharyngeal swabs.
